bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Bennett, November 18, 1952

div1.p: Hench inquires whether the Medical School of Jefferson College or the Medical Alumni Association would be interested in placing a wreath under the medallion of Finlay during the dedication ceremony of Camp Lazear. Finlay graduated from Jefferson Medical College in 1855.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Bennett, November 18, 1952
div1.opener:
11/26/52
Were f Paul Roke
November 18, 1952
Dr. George A. Bennett, Dean
Jefferson Medical College
Philadelphia, Pennsylvania
My dear Doctor Bennett:
div1.p:
On December 3, the anniversary of the birthday of Carlos Finlay, which
is “Physicians' Day in Cuba,” the Cuban Government is memorializing the
remains of Walter Reed's Camp Lazear in Quemados de Marianao. The re-
mains of Building No. 1 have been repaired, a little park has been made
and on a stone wall will be unveiled several individual bronze medallions,
profiles of Finlay, Delgado, Reed, Carroll, Lazear, Agramonte and Wood.
On each side will be a bronze tablet with the names of the volunteers
who served as guinea pigs.

This will be, I believe, a significant occasion because heretofore there
has been, unfortunately, a considerable feeling of animosity in certain
Cuban circles against those who have honored Reed and his colleagues, the
Cuban viewpoint being that American medicine has ignored the great contribu-
tion of Finlay. Now for the first time the Cuban Government is honoring
the contribution of the Americans by memorializing Camp Lazear in this way.
Although I am not certain, it is possible that they may not retain the
name Camp Lazear but may rename the place Perque Finlay. Nevertheless,
the bronze tablets, the dedicatory speeches and so on, will make clear the
significance of this spot and they are making a small but nevertheless fine
beginning towards a better Cuban-American relationship.

I believe the Cuban Government is planning to send invitations to a number
of Americans and American medical institutions. They have been delayed in
doing this because of some uncertainty as to the final date for the dedica-
tion; but the date has now been set for December 3. I know that General
Streit, Commanding General of Walter Reed Hospital, will be there, repre-
senting the Surgeon General and a few others are planning to go. The U. S.
Embassy will be represented and I have been told that President Batista
will participate in the ceremonies.

It seems to me that the Americans who attend this ceremony should not go
empty-handed but should respond in a generous way to the gracious intent
of the Cuban Government and medical profession and thus strengthen the
friendship between the Cuban and American medical professions. It occurred
to me that since Doctor Finlay was a graduate of Jefferson Medical College
(1855), the Medical School or the Medical Alumni ssociation might wish to
have a representative of their institution place a wreath or floral decora-
tion under the medallion of Doctor Finlay on this occasion. Therefore I am
Dr. George A. Bennett
- 2 -
November 18, 1952
writing to you asking whether you would think that would be appropriate. I
am writing similar letters to the other half dozen institutions from which
those who are mainly to be honored obtained their medical degrees.

This merely is a request for information as to whether you would think this
gesture appropriate. If so, I shall communicate by cable with the Cuban
authorities and ask them if they will make a place during the ceremony
for the placing of these wreaths.

If you have an alumnus that lives in Havana (and it need not necessarily
be a physician) it would be most appropriate for him to place the wreath
at the proper time; or better yet, if one of your faculty could go (and
I fear that the Cuban government has no monetary subsidy), that would be
excellent and I will request that a personal invitation he sent for them.
If neither of those are possible. I would myself see to it that the wreath
was placed at the proper time, either by the American Ambassador, by General
Streight, or by myself. However it would be much more effective if a
representative of your institution could do that, providing this sugges-
tion is approved first by you and then by our Cuban hosts.

Our local florist has told me that he thought a circular wreath of laurel
leaves, perhaps 30 inches in diameter, would be appropriate, perhaps with
a silk ribbon either with the colors of the college or red, white and blue
for the United States, at a cost of perhaps $15 or so. Should you approve
the general idea, would you care to have your own representative arrange
for the preparation of the wreath in Havana? If not, I should be glad to
help in any way and could either have the half dozen or so wreaths made
up in Havana a day or two ahead or, according to our local florist, they
can be made up in Miami and flown to Havana and delivered to the appropriate
person for placement.

I would appreciate greatly hearing from you at your earliest convenience.
Enclosed please find a photograph of the blue print and a reprint which will
refresh your mind on the significance of Camp Lazear.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
Enclosures
P.S.: If it seems more appropriate, you might prefer to send a telegraphic
message. The wire could be sent either to His Excellency, Dr. Jose Andreu,
El Ministro de Salubridad y Asistencia Social or to one of his agents in
this matter, Dr. Pedro Nogueira, Marti 219, Marianao, Havana, or Dr. Cesar
Rodriguez, Exposito, Secretary, Marti 219, Marianao, Havana.
